awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Fostering Engineering Creativity and Communication through Immediate, Personalized Feedback on 2D-Perspective Drawing
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest in excellent undergraduate engineering education by improving students’ ability to draw representations of structures and systems.  Free-hand drawing is a crucial skill across engineering, especially for its ability to reduce complex systems to simplified, accurate diagrams. Such diagrams aid in idea generation, visualization of systems, and discussions between clients and engineers.  When coupled with appropriate timely feedback, drawing can also be an effective learning tool for improving students’ visual communication skills and creativity.  This project will use a computer application called SketchTivity to teach engineering students how to draw, and examine the impact of drawing instruction on student learning.  SketchTivity is an intelligent tutoring system that provides real-time feedback on 2D drawings that students make on a screen instead of on paper. The application, which was developed by the research team, provides each student with iterative, real-time, personalized feedback on the drawing, promoting improvements and facilitating learning.  Free-hand drawing and its associated benefits were inadvertently removed from the engineering curricula when educators transitioned from hand drafting to Computer-Aided-Design.  This transition has resulted in the lack of student and faculty proficiency in freehand drawing.  This project will support restoration of 2D-perspective drawing to engineering curricula.  Since drawing is a skill that is also relevant to other STEM fields, this work is likely to have broad relevance in undergraduate STEM education.

The project will enable the distribution of SketchTivity software to approximately 5,000 diverse undergraduate and graduate students at four partnering institutions. These students include a large percentage of women and students from other groups that are not equitably represented in STEM fields.  The project has the potential to produce significant new knowledge about drawing-based artificial intelligence (AI) tools. It can also increase understanding about the effects of feedback and reflective prompts on drawing skills, and on learning and creativity. The project will compare AI-based assessments to assessments conducted by humans, thus providing additional information about development of intelligent tutoring systems. The impact of drawing ability on students’ creativity and spatial reasoning skills will be investigated, along with the transferability of drawing skills to other courses in engineering. A mixed-methods approach that includes surveys, validated assessments for engineering design creativity, and drawing quizzes, is proposed to assess project outcomes. The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

This project advances knowledge in computer science, artificial intelligence, and engineering education by developing novel algorithms that assess the quality of freehand sketches with a level of accuracy comparable to human experts. By leveraging machine learning and computer vision techniques, the project contributes to a deeper understanding of how computers can interpret and evaluate hand-drawn geometric figures and perspective sketches.

The development of SketchTivity, an intelligent tutoring system, represents a significant step forward in natural sketch-based interfaces, enabling personalized, automated feedback to students learning freehand technical sketching. This research not only enhances AI-driven assessment in educational tools but also establishes a framework for integrating sketch recognition into broader engineering education applications.

Additionally, the project has led to the creation of a standardized test for sketching ability, a crucial contribution to engineering pedagogy. This test provides an objective method to evaluate students' spatial visualization and technical sketching skills, which are fundamental to engineering problem-solving. The insights gained from this research inform best practices for integrating digital sketching tools into large-scale engineering courses, ensuring that students can effectively develop essential visual communication skills.

Further contributions of this project include:

  • Sketch Style Pilot Experiment Results: This study demonstrated that sketch style significantly affects engineers’ perceptions of early-stage design concepts. Industrial design and illustrative styles were generally preferred over fine art styles, highlighting the importance of smooth line work in sketching for engineering communication.

  • Systematic Literature Review of Sketching Assessment: This study examined sketching assessment practices across disciplines, identifying common metrics and cognitive processes related to sketching, informing best practices for evaluating sketching skills.

  • Object Assembly Sketching Skills Assessment: The development and validation of the Object Assembly Test demonstrated its effectiveness in measuring 3D sketching skills and improving instructional methods in mechanical engineering courses.

  • Sketching & Idea Generation: This study explored how sketching skills influence ideation effectiveness, finding a mild positive correlation between sketching ability and idea generation quantity while identifying potential drawbacks of over-elaboration.

  • Sketching Behaviors Results: This research revealed that frequent sketching during the design process correlates with positive design outcomes, with early development of spatial and sketching skills predicting increased sketching frequency in later engineering education.

 

Broader Impacts:

The project has made substantial contributions to multiple fields, including:

  • Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence: The development of algorithms for recognizing and assessing freehand sketches has advanced AI-driven evaluation methods, particularly in educational tools for engineering students.

  • Education: The creation of a perspective sketching skills test and analysis of sketching assessment practices have improved pedagogical approaches in engineering education.

  • Mechanical Engineering: Findings from this project demonstrate the effectiveness of sketching instruction in large engineering classes and validate SketchTivity as a scalable tutoring system.

  • Human Resource Development: The project has trained students in computer science, mechanical engineering, and engineering education in research methodologies, academic writing, and project management.

  • Teaching and Educational Experiences: SketchTivity has been successfully implemented in multiple universities, providing a novel digital approach to teaching sketching skills. The research has reinforced the importance of two-point perspective sketching and allocating sufficient classroom time to developing sketching competencies.

These contributions collectively enhance engineering education, improve AI-driven assessment tools, and reinforce the value of sketching in the design process.
